review.title: Converting Instance Checking to Subsumption: A Rethink for Object Queries over Practical Ontologies
review.abstract: Efficiently querying Description Logic (DL) ontologies is becoming a vital task in various data-intensive DL applications. Considered as a basic service for answering object queries over DL ontologies, instance checking can be realized by using the most specific concept (MSC) method, which converts instance checking into subsumption problems. This method, however, loses its simplicity and efficiency when applied to large and complex ontologies, as it tends to generate very large MSC's that could lead to intractable reasoning. In this paper, we propose a revision to this MSC method for DL SHI, allowing it to generate much simpler and smaller concepts that are specific-enough to answer a given query. With independence between computed MSC's, scalability for query answering can also be achieved by distributing and parallelizing the computations. An empirical evaluation shows the efficacy of our revised MSC method and the significant efficiency achieved when using it for answering object queries.

sections.text: 1 Converting Instance Checking to Subsumption: A Rethink for Object Queries over Practical OntologiesJia Xu, Patrick Shironoshita, Ubbo Visser, Nigel John, and Mansur KabukaAbstract - Efficiently querying Description Logic (DL) ontologies is getting a vital task in various data-intensive DL applications. As a basic service for answering object queries via DL ontologies, instance verification can be realized by applying the most specific concept method (MSC) that turns instance verification into submission problems. However, this method loses its simplicity and efficiency when applied to large and complex ontologies, as it tends to generate very large MSC ontologies that could lead to insoluble arguments. In this paper, we propose a revision of this MSC method for DL SHI, thereby generating much simpler and smaller concepts that are specific enough to answer a question.

sections.heading: 6.3 Scalability Evaluation
sections.text: The use of the MSCT method for answering queries over large ontologies is intended for distributed (parallel) computing, but even if it is executed sequentially in a single computer, linear scalability can still be achieved on large ontologies that are not extremely complex; and there are two main reasons for this: firstly, the calculation of MSCTs focuses on only the 13 query-relevant claims instead of the entire ABox; secondly, the obtained MSCTs could be very simple, the size of which could be significantly smaller than that of the ABoxes. We test the scalability of this method for answering queries (executed sequentially) using the benchmark ontology LUBM, which models the organization of universities with each university from approximately 17,000 related persons, and the result is shown in Figure 8.

sections.heading: 7 CONCLUSION AND OUTLOOK
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed a revised MSC method for efficient instance verification, which allows ontological thinking to examine only a much smaller subset of ABox data relevant to a particular instance verification problem, thereby achieving great efficiency and solving the limitations of current memory-based verification techniques. It can be particularly useful for answering object queries via these large non-horn DL ontologies, where existing optimization techniques are too short and answering object queries may require thousands or even millions of instance verification tasks. Most importantly, due to the independence between the MSCTs, scalability for responding to queries via huge ontologies (e.g. when setting semantic networks) can also be achieved by parallelizing calculations. Our technique currently works for SHI logic, which is semi-expressive and requires for many practical ontologies to use more fully logic.

metadata.abstractText: Efficiently querying Description Logic (DL) ontologies is becoming a vital task in various data-intensive DL applications. Considered as a basic service for answering object queries over DL ontologies, instance checking can be realized by using the most specific concept (MSC) method, which converts instance checking into subsumption problems. This method, however, loses its simplicity and efficiency when applied to large and complex ontologies, as it tends to generate very large MSC’s that could lead to intractable reasoning. In this paper, we propose a revision to this MSC method for DL SHI, allowing it to generate much simpler and smaller concepts that are specific-enough to answer a given query. With independence between computed MSC’s, scalability for query answering can also be achieved by distributing and parallelizing the computations. An empirical evaluation shows the efficacy of our revised MSC method and the significant efficiency achieved when using it for answering
